I am surprised that no one as brought this up yet.
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7053246.stm
 
 I find it kind of ironic when you have the UK and the US urging restraint in the use of force to solve this problem. 
 
 Also shouldn't the UK/US support Turkey in its actions? 
 
 After all the UK/US supported Israel's invasion of the Lebanon to destroy a Terrorist organisation, why not support the Turks who are in the exact same position?

Because Kurdistan is one of the few stable places in Iraq. And we don't want to end up fighting Turkish troops. 
 
 But yes it is hypocritical. 
 
 I suspect if the US showed a effort to wipe out the PKK then the Turks would deescalate. But we haven't done so.

It seems that the talks in Bagdad have cooled down the situation.
 
 The PKK is the problem for it is not under the control of the Kurdish government.
I think the problem is persistant Turkish oppression of ethnic minorities, particularly the Kurds. What happened to the UN commitment to self-determination?

True, the Turks practiced genocide before the Germans did. They tried to exterminate the Armenians and almost succeeded. 
 The Kurds have been mounting guerrilla attacks on Iran with the connivance of the Americans, they have killed more Iranians than Turks but Iran can not retaliate as Turkey has done, since retaliation would give the Americans an excuse to bomb Iran.
